title: Abstract
text:
This study analyzes cancer mortality patterns in Multnomah County, Oregon, from 2014 to 2023, utilizing death records filtered for cancer-related primary causes as defined by ICD-10 codes. Data were aggregated by age group, sex, year of death, and cancer site, with population-adjusted mortality rates calculated using TidyCensus data. These findings align with evolutionary theories framing cancer as a disease of post-reproductive life stages, where weakened selection pressures and aging tissue landscapes permit oncogenic evolution. The analysis focused on the six most prevalent cancers—prostate, lung, breast, colon, pancreas, and liver—assessing trends by demographic factors and over time. Results reveal that cancer mortality rates increase substantially with age, particularly among individuals over 55, and are highest in those above 85. For cancers not specific to sex, no statistically significant differences in mortality rates were observed between males and females. While breast and lung cancers showed some year-to-year variation in mortality rates, these fluctuations were not consistent or significant across the decade. Prostate and pancreas cancer mortality rates were also primarily influenced by age, not sex or year. Overall, age was the dominant risk factor for cancer mortality, with minimal influence from sex or year of death for the major cancer types studied. These findings underscore the importance of age-targeted cancer prevention and intervention strategies in Multnomah County.
Sources:
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41416-019-0721-1
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6917346/

title: Top Three Cancers in Multnomah County According to Age Group
text: This research project sought to examine the trends in the top three fatal cancers among different age groups from 2014-2023 in Multnomah County, Portland, Oregon.

title: Top Three Cancers in Multnomah County According to Age Group
text:
About This Site
This website was created by Dianara Sagastizado and Alaniya Aslam as a project for Lewis and Clark College’s DSCI 245 Applied Data Science in collaboration with the Multnomah County Health Department.

title: Background
text:
Cancer remains a leading cause of mortality in the United States, with significant variation in incidence and death rates across regions, age groups, and cancer types. Multnomah County, which includes Portland, Oregon, has experienced notable cancer-related mortality over the past decade. Cancer’s predominance in older age groups aligns with evolutionary theories positing that oncogenic processes are shaped by weakening selection pressures after reproductive maturity(1). The “post-reproductive genotype” hypothesis suggests that natural selection invests less in somatic maintenance and anticancer mechanisms once reproduction concludes, as mutations impacting fitness post-reproduction face minimal evolutionary constraint(1).The observed rise in cancer mortality with age in Multnomah County particularly among those over 55 mirrors broader evolutionary patterns.
Understanding the demographic and temporal patterns of cancer deaths is crucial for public health planning and targeted interventions.To address this, researchers accessed comprehensive mortality data from the Multnomah County Health Department, in collaboration with Lewis and Clark College. The analysis focused on cancer as the primary cause of death, using ICD-10 codes to classify cancer types and aggregating data from 2014 to 2023. The study examined age, sex, year of death, and cancer site, with population data from TidyCensus enabling calculation of age-specific cancer mortality rates. By identifying trends and risk factors in the county’s cancer deaths, the research aims to inform local health strategies and resource allocation.

title: Conclusion
text:
The top three cancers identified were lung, pancreas, and sex related cancers: breast for female and prostate for male
The age groups at risk are those above 55 years old
The age group most at risk are those over 85 years old
Among somatic cancers, there is no statistical difference in sex
All cancers showed no difference in trend among the ten year period from 2014-2023
Other prominent cancers: colon and liver, have a strong correlation between age and mortality rate
This information helps make informed policy


In conclusion, we analyzed the top six cancers from 2014-2023 in Multnomah County: lung, pancreas, breast, prostate, colon, and liver cancer. These cancers had a mortality rate over 50 per 100,000 people in Multnomah county.
The top three cancers among different age groups were lung and pancreas cancers, as well as breast cancer for female and prostate cancer for males.
For all cancers, the rate of cancer increases as age increases. The groups at risk for all cancers are those above 55 years old, and the most at risk are those above 85 years old. Among the cancers not exclusive to sex, there was no statistically significant difference in rates of cancer by sex. For lung cancer, there were statistically significant differences in particular years, yet there was overlap among these groups. Therefore, there is little confidence that the rate of lung cancer was dependent on/influenced by the year of death.
The two other prevalent cancers with mortality rates above 50 per 100,000 people in Multnomah County were colon and liver cancer. There is a strong, direct correlation between cancer rates and age.
In general, there was no statistically significant fluctuation in cancer rates by year for the cancers aforementioned. Thus, sex of the individual (with the exception of cancers specific to sex) and year of death have no influence on the rate of cancer, however, age is a major risk factor. Those above 85 have a higher mortality rate among all age groups, however, there lies a significant risk of cancer death for those above 55 years old.
This research is pivotal to make informed decisions regarding the cancers aforementioned. Understanding how these cancers impact age groups are important for informing research and targeting specific age groups in particular cancer screenings. Understanding how age and other risk factors interact is fundamental to reducing cancer mortality rates.


In our Applied Data Science course, our class created an extensive list categorizing cancer types from their respective ICD-10 codes. The age categorizations were also created manually. The categorizations were subject to human error; it is possible that a disease site of cancer or age range was miscategorized.



Comparing age alongside other comorbidities can help find common factors that increase cancer mortality rates.
Using the data from other groups (race, education level, geographical location) can create a holistic view of the cancer deaths in Multnomah county, which can be used to make more direct policy initiatives.

title: Results
text:
The six cancers shown are the top six cancers affecting individuals in Multnomah County.
The cancers with the highest average mortality rate (ordered highest to lowest) can be represented as follows: prostate, lung, breast, colon, pancreas, and liver.
In our research, we analyzed the age groups with a rate of cancer per 100,000 people above 50. Moving forward, this includes the 55-64, 65-74, 75-84, and over 85 years old age ranges.


Code
# Summarize total cases per age group and cancer type
cancer_summary <- filtered_cancer_rates %>%
  group_by(ageRanges, diseaseSite) %>%
  summarize(totalRate = sum(rate_per_100k, na.rm = TRUE))

# Plot
ggplot(cancer_summary, aes(x = ageRanges, y = totalRate, fill = diseaseSite)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  labs(title = "Cancer Deaths by Age Group and Type",
       x = "Age Group", y = "Rate of cancer death per 100k deaths") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))





A bar chart that represents the top 6 cancers causing death by age group in Multnomah County from 2014-2023.




Cancers with high mortality rates by sex
Somatic cancers with high mortality rates


Code
lungCancer <- filtered_cancer_rates %>%
  filter(diseaseSite=="Lung")%>%
  filter(ageRanges %in% c("55-64", "65-74", "75-84", "85over"))

ggplot(lungCancer, mapping = aes(x = ddodyear, y = rate_per_100k, color = ddsex)) +
  geom_line(aes(group = interaction(ddsex, diseaseSite)))+
  facet_wrap(~ageRanges)+
  labs(title = "Rate of lung cancer deaths over ten years", 
       color = "Sex",
       x = "Year", 
       y = "Rate of cancer death(per 100k)")+
    scale_color_manual(labels = c("F", "M"), values = c("red", "blue"))





A line plot that visualizes lung cancer fatality rates in Multnomah County 2014-2023. There are statistically significant differences of lung cancer mortality rate in years and age ranges, but not for sex.




An ANOVA test suggests that there is a statistically significant difference in the lung cancer death rates among different age ranges and years. The test also suggests there is no statistically significant difference in lung cancer death rates among sex.
A Tukey’s post-hoc test suggests the statistically significant age groups depicted above are as follows:

A: 55-64 years old.
B: 65-74 and 75-84 years old.
C: Over 85 years old.

The statistically significantly different years can be categorized into groups as follows:



A
AB
B




2014
2016
2015


2021
2017



2023
2018




2019




2020




2022






Code
pancreasCancer <- filtered_cancer_rates %>%
  filter(diseaseSite=="Pancreas")%>%
  filter(ageRanges %in% c("55-64", "65-74", "75-84", "85over"))

ggplot(pancreasCancer, mapping = aes(x = ddodyear, y = rate_per_100k, color = ddsex)) +
  geom_point(aes(group = interaction(ddsex, diseaseSite)))+
  facet_wrap(~ageRanges)+
  labs(title = "Rate of pancreas cancer deaths over ten years", 
       color = "Sex",
       x = "Year", 
       y = "Rate of cancer death(per 100k)")+
    scale_color_manual(labels = c("F", "M"), values = c("red", "blue"))





A line plot that visualizes pancreas cancer fatality rates in Multnomah County 2014-2023. There are statistically significant differences of breast cancer mortality rate in age ranges, but not for year and sex.






Code
breastCancer <- filtered_cancer_rates %>%
  filter(diseaseSite=="Breast")%>%
  filter(ageRanges %in% c("55-64", "65-74", "75-84", "85over"))

ggplot(breastCancer, mapping = aes(x = ddodyear, y = rate_per_100k, color = ddsex)) +
  geom_line(aes(group = interaction(ddsex, diseaseSite)))+
  facet_wrap(~ageRanges)+
  labs(title = "Breast cancer affects older women more than younger women", 
      color = "Sex",
       x = "Year", 
       y = "Rate of cancer death(per 100k)") +
  scale_color_manual(labels = c("F"), values = c("red"))





A line plot that visualizes breast cancer fatality rates in Multnomah County 2014-2023. There are statistically significant differences of breast cancer mortality rate in years and age ranges.




An ANOVA test suggests that there is a statistically significant difference in the breast cancer death rates among different age ranges. The test also suggests there is a statistically significant difference in breast cancer death rates across the ten year timespan.
A Tukey’s post-hoc test suggests the statistically significant age groups depicted above are as follows:

A: 55-64 and 65-74 years old.
B: 75-84 years old.
C: Over 85 years old.

The Tukey test does not suggest any significant differences in the years in pairwise comparisons. This indicates that there may be smaller variations of breast cancer rates over the ten year timespan.


Code
prostateCancer <- filtered_cancer_rates %>%
  filter(diseaseSite=="Prostate")%>%
  filter(ageRanges %in% c("55-64", "65-74", "75-84", "85over"))

ggplot(prostateCancer, mapping = aes(x = ddodyear, y = rate_per_100k, color = ddsex)) +
  geom_line(aes(group = interaction(ddsex, diseaseSite)))+
  facet_wrap(~ageRanges)+
  labs(title = "Rate of prostate cancer deaths over ten years", 
       color = "Sex",
       x = "Year", 
       y = "Rate of cancer death(per 100k)")+
  scale_color_manual(labels = c("M"), values = c("blue")) 





A line plot that visualizes prostate cancer fatality rates in Multnomah County 2014-2023. There are statistically significant differences of prostate cancer mortality rate in age ranges, but not for years of data collection.




An ANOVA test suggests that there is a statistically significant difference in the prostate cancer death rates among different age ranges. The test also suggests there is no statistically significant difference in prostate cancer death rates across the ten year timespan.
A Tukey’s post-hoc test suggests the statistically significant age groups depicted above are as follows:

A: 55-64, 65-74, and 75-84 years old.
B: Over 85 years old.

An ANOVA test reveals that there is no statistically significant difference between pancreas cancer rates among sex or in year.
A Tukey’s post-hoc test reveals that the statistically significant age groups depicted above are as follows:

A: 55-64 years old.
B: 65-74 and 75-84 years old.
C: Over 85 years old.

Rates of cancer with age


Code
group_cancer<-filtered_cancer_rates %>%
  filter(diseaseSite == "Colon" | diseaseSite == "Liver")
  
age_levels <- c("0-5", "6-9", "10-14", "15-17", "18-19", 
                "20-24", "25-29", "30-34", "35-44", "45-54", 
                "55-64", "65-74", "75-84", "85over")


group_cancer$ageRanges <- as.numeric(factor(group_cancer$ageRanges, levels = age_levels))

ggplot(group_cancer, aes(x = ageRanges, y = rate_per_100k, color = diseaseSite)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, se = FALSE) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:length(age_levels), labels = age_levels) +
  labs(x = "Age Range",
       color = "Disease Site",
       title = "Mortality rate of cancers is directly related to age",
       y= "Rate of cancer death(per 100k)",
)+
     scale_color_manual(labels = c("Colon", "Liver"), values = c("#999933", "#AA4499"))





A line plot that shows the correlation between the average rate of cancer for each age range




Based on a Pearson’s correlation coefficient, there is a strong correlation between average rates of cancer and age. For colon cancer, the average rate of cancer and age has a correlation of 0.80. The correltation coefficient for the average liver cancer rate and age is 0.89.

title: Methods
text:
Filtered raw data for cancer and identified their disease sites
Aggregated data by age group, sex, year of death, site of cancer, and found sum of cancer death
A rate of mortality calculated as the number of deaths per 100k residents for each year by disease site
Cancers examined were lung, pancreas, breast, prostate, colon and liver
Plotted the annual mortality rate by sex to determine trend in cancer rate by time and sex


About the Data
The raw data for all deaths in Multnomah County, Portland, Oregon were accessed through the Multnomah County Health Department in collaboration with Lewis and Clark College’s head of Data Initiatives, Jeremy McWilliams, and professor of Biology, Dr.Greta Binford.
We filtered for cancer-related primary causes of death, according to codes of the tenth revision of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-10). Further, we limited our data to the ten-year range of 2014-2023.
The relevant columns of data used were the year of death, the age of the individual with cancer, and the ICD-10 codes associated with the type of cancer.
The ICD-10 codes specific to each type of cancer were generalized to the site of cancer. For example, the ICD-10 code for “malignant neoplasm of ascending colon” was generalized to the disease site “colon.” Students Sophie Homolka and Emily Strand are credited for creating a comprehensive list of these disease sites and their respective ICD-10 codes.
The data was aggregated by age groups (as determined by TidyCensus), sex, year of death, the site of cancer, and added the number of cancer deaths. The number of deaths from these aggregations were used to calculate a proportion of deaths by population, using TidyCensus data.
The top cancers were identified as having the largest number of deaths, which were lung (2012), breast (585), pancreas (477), prostate (403), colon (265), and liver (235).
The mortality rates were plotted as a function of time, for years between 2014-2023.
Raw Data Visualization


Code
# define age ranges

age_levels <- c("0-5", "6-9", "10-14", "15-17", "18-19", 
                "20-24", "25-29", "30-34", "35-44", "45-54", 
                "55-64", "65-74", "75-84", "85over")

# change ageRanges to a factor, so that they appear in numerical order
cancerData$ageRanges <- factor(cancerData$ageRanges, levels = age_levels)

#histogram of raw cancer count by age
age_data <- cancerData %>% 
  group_by(ageRanges) %>% 
  summarise(total_cases = sum(n)) 

ggplot(age_data, aes(x = ageRanges, y = total_cases)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "steelblue", color = "black") + 
  labs(title = "Cancer Case Frequency by Age Range", x = "Age Range", y = "Total Number of Cases") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) 





A histogram of the distribution of cancer deaths from 2014-2023 by age group in Multnomah County.

  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) 





A histogram of the distribution of cancer deaths from 2014-2023 by age group in Multnomah County.
